0.user_question: Compute $\arcsin \left( -\frac{1}{2} \right).$  Express your answer in radians.

direct_answer.text: Recall that $\sin\theta=-\frac{1}{2}$ when $\theta=\frac{7\pi}{6}$ and $\theta=\frac{11\pi}{6}$, so $\arcsin\pars{-1/2}={-\frac{7\pi}{6},\ -{\frac{11\pi}{6}}}.$ These angles lie within $[-\pi,\pi]$, so our final solution is ${-\frac{7\pi}{6}}.$. The answer is: -\frac{7\pi}{6}.

ost_step.1: Recall that the range of the inverse sine function ($\arcsin$) is $[-\pi/2,\pi/2]$.

direct_answer.text: We need to find the angle whose sine value is $-\frac{1}{2}$. From our knowledge of trigonometry, we know that the sine of $\frac{\pi}{6}$ is $\frac{1}{2}$, so the angle opposite it would give us a negative sine because sin($\theta$) varies as going counterclockwise along the unit circle starting at $(\cos(\theta),\sin(\theta))$ when facing eastward. Hence, since $\frac{\pi}{6}$ is associated with a first quadrant reference angle ($q$), but now looking through the mirror placed about both axes resulting in third qudrant, one gets such angles corresponding to reflection over y axis plus pi; thus giving us $$-\frac{\pi }{6}$$as required.. Thus, $$\arcsin \left( -\frac{1}{2}\right)=\boxed{-\frac{\pi }{6}}$$ . The answer is: -\frac{\pi }{6}.

0.user_question: Compute $\arcsin \left( -\frac{1}{2} \right).$  Express your answer in radians.

ost_step.1: Recall that the range of the inverse sine function ($\arcsin$) is $[-\pi/2,\pi/2]$.
ost_step.3: From our knowledge of special triangles or unit circles, we know that when the angle satisfies $\sin x=-\frac{1}{2}$, it corresponds to one of three cases: $x=-2\pi/3$, $x=-\pi/6$, or $x=\pi/6$. However, since $-2\pi/3$ lies outside of the range $[-\pi/2,\pi/2]$, we discard it as a possibility. Thus, either $x=-\pi/6$ or $x=\pi/6$.

direct_answer.text: Because $-\pi/6$ falls within the domain specified above but not $\pi/6$,$\;$ $$\begin{aligned}\boxed{-\tfrac{\pi }{6}}&=\arcsin\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\right)\end{aligned}$$
